conclusion: A basketball of mass m is dropped from rest at a height H above the ground. It undergoes an inelastic collision with the ground and rebounds to a maximum height h above the ground. The magnitude of the air resistance experienced by the basketball during its motion is λ times the magnitude of the gravitational force acting on the basketball (where λ is a constant and 0<λ<(H-h)/(H+h)). The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is the same for each collision with the ground. The magnitude of the gravitational acceleration is g.
Determine the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground.
To determine the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground, we'll follow these steps:
Forces Acting Downwards: Gravitational force: mg, Air resistance: λmg

premise: Net force acting downwards: mg + λmg = mg(1 + λ)

conclusion: vd^2 = 2g(1 + λ)H implies vd = sqrt(2g(1 + λ)H)
Forces Acting Upwards: Gravitational force: mg, Air resistance: λmg

premise: Net force acting upwards: mg - λmg = mg(1 - λ)

conclusion: vu^2 = 2g(1 - λ)h implies vu = sqrt(2g(1 - λ)h)

premise: Ratio of Upward to Downward Velocities
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground is sqrt((1 - λ)h/(1 + λ)H)
